Speaker Nancy Pelosi and the House Demcoratic caucus are right. This bill should be amended on the basis of equity.

I applaud compromise. This bill can still be improved. I stand with the House Democrats who seek to reduce the estate tax concessions. I also favor eliminating the Bush tax cuts for families and individuals making $1 million or more per year. We are living in grim economic times and sacrifice should be shared.

Future historians will look back in wonder and contempt at a declining civilization that foolishly and ignorantly thought its government could slash revenue and increase spending, and survive.  This country is a joke designed to serve the uber-rich.

Our government needs to make an anouncement to the world that if we are ever attacked with a nuclear device from an extremist Islamic group that we will make Mecca glow for 10,000 years. Its called mutually assured destruction and it worked in the cold war when we had a defined state enemy.This is the only thing that our enemy holds dear now that we are fighting an idea with shadowy groups of fighters.

Am I in a time warp?  Fallout shelters against a nuclear attack.  Did we forget that nuclear bombs today are at least a thousand times more powerful than the ones dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki?  Radiological fallout doesn't just drift away in a few hours. Its toxic effect clings to every square inch of earth, buildings, bridges, foliage, pane of glass for at least 80 years. There is no escape from this kind of attack. Yet there is a solution. Meet the beast head-on. America has a golden opportunity now to take the initiative in leading the world to abolish nuclear weapons. And we don't have to do it alone. There is one law that has prevented Japan from building a nuclear bomb. It is a law that U.S. Occupation forces wrote for the Japanese Constitution in 1946. Article Nine forbids Japan to ever make war again. Now is the time for the U.S. to adapt their own version of Article Nine for our own Constitution. Then the two nations Japan and the USA can form a coalition to spearhead the abolition of nuclear weapons and the abolition of war making as a political tool. Sound crazy?  Never more so than the invention and use of atomic bombs

I just love that word -- katabatic -- and remember huge winds coming off the Tasman Sea, channeling through the Cook Straits off Wellington that I thought of as being from Antarctica though they are unrelated.

At one time I was privileged to visit the U.S. Antarctic station in Christchurch and learn a bit about our program -- the challenges to mental and physical health it presents. I recall a story about a woman scientist dressed in white tee shirt/black pants, out on the ice one warmish morning, leaning over an ice hole.

A leopard seal -- mistaking her for a penguin -- leapt out, grasp her leg in its jaws and began to draw her under before realizing its error.

Seals never seemed quite as friendly to me after that.

My lasting memory is that each year we send artists down to record their impressions. Bless our government for that insight, and do read Barry Lopez's work.

I love these dispatches from Antarctica. It always seems like the ultimate adventure.
You couldn't get me there at gunpoint but I do love reading about the place.

I moved to Manhattan in 1989. The Lower East Side and the East Village were MUCH different than they are now. It was dicey and you had to be careful. But like lots of wanna-be artists I had a succession of day jobs and eventually found a job at Pearl Paint. The 2nd floor crew, of which I was part of, would often saunter across town to Max Fish for beers (Rolling Rock was the trendy choice back then) and maybe some pool. Lots of lively discussion, posing and posturing, drunken debates. It was fun to be young and living in such an edgy city back then. The bar scene on the East Side below 14th back then was seedy and exciting. Anybody frequent the Pyramid Club back then?

I first saw these fallout shelters in 1980 when I went to the US to study and had no idea what they were. To me that whole thing was shocking.

With all the security measures around us, I agree with the statement that any terrorist actually getting hold of a nuclear weapon and then bringing it over to the US is nearly zero.

However, here is something to think about: sometime in 1990 I was about to go to an Italian restaurant on the corner of Westheimer Road and Crossview Drive in Houston I saw an Army truck parked. Guess what was on that truck? It was loaded with VERY LARGE bombs - lots of them in OPEN VIEW, and there was NO Security around them, NONE, no driver inside. Now, that is something to think about!!! If the US Government leave them lying aroud somewhere for some idiot to get hold of them then we are in serious trouble.

How would I react to a nuclear attack? First, I would run like hell to get down into the deepest subway I could find, like several hundred feet underground. How would I react? I would be very angry at the party who attacked and would write to the President to return fire, a lot of it.

On the other hand, instead of pondering how to react to a nuclear attack, I would rather invest whatever resources available to prevent a nuclear attack in the first place. One way to do that is to eliminate nuclear weapons programs before they yield nuclear weapons, as in the case of Iran. Use of MAD has worked perfectly since both the US and the Soviets developed nuclear weapons, and is an effective deterrent at least for countries concerned with their continued existence. I don't know if this would work with radical Islamic countries where dying in holy war or Jihad can provide an express pathway to heaven.
So, the fiscal conservative Republicans added a $Trillion to our defecit. To further stall our economy and lower wages. Taking away our kids future.

U.S. now runs a deficit of about $1.3 trillion

In sharp contrast, Former President Bill Clinton left a record surplus, despite the warning of potential economic disaster over tax increase for the wealthiest.

Sanders' amendment calls for stripping out the tax breaks for the wealthiest 2 percent. That money would have instead been spent on deficit reduction and infrastructure needs.

These enormous tax cuts have led to record federal deficits, contributed to the government's current financial woes, and have not helped many Americans who face the greatest financial burdens," Leahy said,
